Comments.x: there is a native phoneme /ɾ/, attested in very few words mostly onomatopeic which has an allophone /l/. the distinction between /ɾ/ and /l/ is saved in spanish loans. /ɾ/ appears in several names taken from Huambisa. the phoneme /ɾ/ is not associated with historical Chicham rhotic.
name: Aguaruna
Central Aymara
rhotic_comment: [r̝] seems to be an allophone of /r/. /r/ contrasts with /ɾ/ (in the speech of bilinguals), the way it does in Spanish.

Comments.x: defined as 'voiced sibilant trill'. Appears also as an allophone of native /ɾ/ in the environment of /s/.
name: Central Aymara
rhotic_comment: [r̝] seems to be an allophone of /r/. /r/ contrasts with /ɾ/ (in the speech of bilinguals), the way it does in Spanish.

Comments.x: Found only in ad hoc borrowings (code-switches)
name: Chiliwack
rhotic_comment: Not sure whether a trill or an approximant

Comments.x: [ɾ] is an allophone of /t/ in native phonology.
name: Gants

Comments.x: allophone of /ɭ/, appears as a separate phoneme only in names taken from Tok Pisin
name: Konai

Comments.x: allophone of /l/ in native phonology (northern dialect)
name: Migabac

Comments.x: The phonemes /l/, /r/ and /rr/ only occur in onomatopoetic words, sound symbolic words and loan words. Source language: Spanish?
name: Oluta Popoluca

Comments.x: The phonemes /l/, /r/ and /rr/ only occur in onomatopoetic words, sound symbolic words and loan words.
name: Oluta Popoluca

Comments.x: phoneme appears in onomatopeia and one explative
name: Sochiapam Chinantec

Comments.x: [r] occurs as an allophone of /t/ and /d/ in postnasal contexts, but outside of those contexts it is clear Sotho-Tswana influence. Whether allophonic [n(d)r] occurred before the introduction of /r/ is unknown at this point, so whether this was a case of the introduction of a new phoneme or phonologization of an allophone is not certain. Source language: Northern Sotho or Tswana
name: Sumayela Ndebele

Comments.x: [rʰ] is a Sanskrit remnant and occurs only in a select few words in the careful speech of educated people
name: Assamese
rhotic_comment: from Sanskrit, which has distinctiove aspiration in its rhotics. see PHOIBLE

Comments.x: (only attested in the loanword tractor > tractorwo)
LanguageName: Wichí Lhamtés Güisnay (Misón La Paz dialect)
name: Wichí Lhamtés Güisnay

Comments.x: "The consonants in parentheses in the chart have a marginal status and occur in Arabic and English loanwords, or as the result of phonological processes."
name: Nubi
rhotic_comment: doesn't seem to be borrowed, see wellens2003nubi: 39

Comments.x: in young people's speech appears as an allophone of /d/.
name: Helong

Comments.x: historical rhotic changed to a prestopped velar lateral /g͡L/.
name: Hiw

Comments.x: [ɾ] appears as an allophone of /d/ in native phonology.
name: Kagan Kalagan

Comments.x: allophone of /l/ in native phonology. Exact phonetic description is not given.
name: Mansaka

Comments.x: appears also in ideophones. inherited Malay words have a velar fricative phoneme /ɣ/.
name: Kelantan-Pattani Malay

Comments.x: allophone of /d/ in native phonology. many loanwords are pronounced according to native phonology. no minimal pairs. Source language: Sabah Malay
name: Timugon Murut
Tsou
rhotic_comment: from Japanese, marked /l/ in the source. maybe check more. The native /r/ ([ɻ]) is analyzed by Tung et al. (in "A descriptive study of the Tsou language, Formosa") as a dialectal vocalic phoneme that can usually be substituted with /e/

Comments.x: exact phonetic representation is not given.
name: Yuaga

Comments.x: it's not specified if it is a trill rothic or a tap rothic, although from the transcriptions it should be trill
name: Chamicuro

Comments.x: /r/ was only noted in one word: [bárá] 'work' loaned from Dioula Tagbusi.
Comments.y: the status of /z/ might have been affected by the introduction of loan words into the Koyaga language.
name: Koyaga

Comments.x:
Only in Tarma dialect it is a phonologization of an allophone. 
In San Pedro de Cajas dialect it is a new phoneme.
Comments.y: Should we consider this grammar as two different doculects? Glottolog doesn't do so, but for our project it would be definatelly clearer, because sometimes the same sound is borrowed in one dialect but not in the other or sometimes it is a new phoneme in one dialect but a distrubutional change in the other.
name: North Junín Quechua

Comments.x:
only one example for such a word: 
[tɹéndʒà]
'stranger, guest' 
from English 
pg. 9
name: Weh

Comments.x:
Only one example:
[dùɾù]
'ox'
from Fulfulde 
pg. 9
name: Weh

Comments.x: Also in onomatopeic sounds and bird calls
name: Zulu

Comments.x:
could be ɾ as it is a liquid.
contrasts with [l]
name: Fuliiru

Comments.x: restricted distribution as an allophone of /l/ intervocally. Few words containing [r] are attested in the speech of a few educated speakers. These, I think, are words that are not yet fully integrated into the sound system of the language. In most words, /r/ in loanwords appears as [l]. does [r] occur in the relevant english variety? Source language uncertain
name: Bafut
Chaldean Neo-Aramaic
rhotic_comment: The source doesn't list borrowed phonemes

Comments.x: rarely in native words - onomatopoeias and sound-symbolic words
name: Itzá

Comments.x: natively never word-initially, borrowing has broadened its distribution
name: Mongolian
Sanandaj
rhotic_comment: See mccarus2009kurdish: 592 for rhotic distinction in Kurdish

name: Hindi
rhotic_comment: From sanskrit, where it is an allophone of /ɳ/

name: Tagalog
rhotic_comment: Not sure if a new phoneme
